Hello all,

I noticed recently that the input nodes in (Jason's C++) HyperN=
EAT are sigmoid functions. In other words, the input is passed through the =
sigmoid before anything else. 

Do most of you (either in NEAT or HyperNEAT=
) pass your inputs through functions immediately? If so, why? 

I tend to t=
hink of the raw inputs as similar to the output of a node, not as an input =
to the function of a node. It makes more sense to me to leave the inputs in=
 their raw form, and let evolution decide to connect to the raw input, or p=
re-process it in some way before using it. 

The sigmoids in the C++ HyperN=
EAT are actually quite linear in the [-1, 1] range of inputs, so I doubt th=
e use of the sigmoid has a large effect in my experiments, but I was curiou=
s if there was any benefit of passing inputs through a node/function that I=
 was not thinking of.
